docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama dipped back into the volatile politics of health care on Tuesday, using a question and answer session to attack his Republican critics and remind senior citizens that the proverbial check - a new $250 rebate to help them pay for prescription drugs - is about to go in the mail.

headline.main: Obama Renews Health Care Sales Pitch

docs.abstract: Q&A session with seniors is aimed at highlighting a $250 rebate for prescription drugs -- and warning against scams aimed at that money.
docs.snippet: Q&A session with seniors is aimed at highlighting a $250 rebate for prescription drugs -- and warning against scams aimed at that money.

docs.lead_paragraph: Few industries benefit more from contentious legislation than lobbyists in Washington. And the fight over the proposed overhaul of financial regulation has been no exception, bringing work to a passel of K Street firms.

headline.main: A Rundown of the Big Financial Services Lobbyists

docs.abstract: A handful of lobbying firms have dominated the business of representing financial services firms in their efforts to battle an overhaul of regulations governing the industry, according to an analysis by the Center for Public Integrity.
docs.snippet: A handful of lobbying firms have dominated the business of representing financial services firms in their efforts to battle an overhaul of regulations governing the industry, according to an analysis by the Center for Public Integrity.

docs.lead_paragraph: A variety of consumer-focused articles appear daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

docs.lead_paragraph: At least 30 states will have to close shortfalls in the coming fiscal year unless Congress passes a six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid.

headline.seo: Counting on Medicaid Money, States Face Shortfalls
headline.main: Medicaid Cut Places States in Budget Bind
headline.print_headline: Medicaid Cut Places States In Budget Bind

docs.snippet: At least 30 states will have to close shortfalls in the coming fiscal year unless Congress passes a six-month extension of increased federal spending on Medicaid.

docs.lead_paragraph: ALBANY -- State lawmakers approved $775 million in cuts and other savings from New York's health care budget on Monday after Gov. David A. Paterson inserted the reductions into emergency spending legislation submitted to the Legislature to keep the state government from shutting down. The cuts will affect hospitals, nursing homes and a lengthy list of other health-related programs, and marked the first significant step in weeks toward an agreement on the state's annual budget, now more than two months overdue. The legislation also requires the state to save an additional $300 million a year by cracking down on Medicaid fraud, waste and abuse.

headline.main: In Albany, Lawmakers Pass Big Health Care Cuts

docs.snippet: The cuts, a step toward a budget agreement, will affect hospitals, nursing homes and other programs.
